articles.headline: U.S. Jets to Use Turkish Bases in War on ISIS
articles.snippet: The development, described by the Americans as a “game changer,” came as Turkish forces engaged in the first direct combat with ISIS on the Syrian border.
articles.abstract: The development, described by the Americans as a “game changer,” came as Turkish forces engaged in the first direct combat with ISIS on the Syrian border.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey plunged into the fight against the Islamic State on Thursday, rushing forces into the first direct combat with its militants on the Syrian border and granting permission for American warplanes to use two Turkish air bases for bombarding the group in Syria.
articles.byline: By Ceylan Yeginsu and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Ruth Porat May Be Just What Investors Think Google Needs
articles.snippet: With the arrival of Ruth Porat as Google’s chief financial officer, the corporate culture shifts to mature and fiscally responsible from impulsive and undisciplined.
articles.abstract: With the arrival of Ruth Porat as Google’s chief financial officer, the corporate culture shifts to mature and fiscally responsible from impulsive and undisciplined.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adult supervision is back at Google.

articles.headline: In Connecticut, the Twilight of a Trading Hub
articles.snippet: Moves by the Royal Bank of Scotland and UBS to shrink operations in Stamford, Conn., are hitting the once booming Wall Street outpost hard.
articles.abstract: Moves by the Royal Bank of Scotland and UBS to shrink operations in Stamford, Conn., are hitting the once booming Wall Street outpost hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, traders and bankers would gather for “power hour” at the Morton’s steakhouse across the street from the train station in Stamford, Conn. Morton’s red awning waved like an invitation at the base of a hulking 13-story building that held the operations of the Swiss bank UBS.

articles.headline: Autopsy of Sandra Bland Finds Injuries Consistent With Suicide, Prosecutor Says
articles.snippet: The injuries suffered by Ms. Bland, who died in a Texas jail cell three days after a minor traffic stop, did not have telltale signs of someone else having killed her, a prosecutor said.
articles.abstract: The injuries suffered by Ms. Bland, who died in a Texas jail cell three days after a minor traffic stop, did not have telltale signs of someone else having killed her, a prosecutor said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, Tex. — A county prosecutor in Texas said Thursday that an autopsy of Sandra Bland, who died in a jail cell here nearly two weeks ago after a minor traffic stop, concluded that her injuries were consistent with suicide, not homicide, a finding that underscored growing doubts that the jail did enough to monitor her.
articles.byline: By David Montgomery and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Amazon Reports Unexpected Profit, and Stock Soars
articles.snippet: A reason for the company’s success has been its cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services, which generated $1.82 billion in revenue last quarter.
articles.abstract: A reason for the company’s success has been its cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services, which generated $1.82 billion in revenue last quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: We have reached Peak Amazon, or perhaps Prime Amazon.

articles.headline: Government Pension Cuts Tangled in Patchwork of Legal Rulings
articles.snippet: Steps taken by states and cities to rein in pension plans have resulted in a tide of litigation, with vexing and sometimes contradictory results.
articles.abstract: Steps taken by states and cities to rein in pension plans have resulted in a tide of litigation, with vexing and sometimes contradictory results.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, lawmakers in Puerto Rico faced the soaring cost of government pensions and did what lawmakers across the United States have been doing: They cut the pensions.

articles.headline: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Hold Dim View of Race Relations
articles.snippet: By comparison, two-thirds of Americans surveyed shortly after President Obama took office said they believed race relations were generally good.
articles.abstract: By comparison, two-thirds of Americans surveyed shortly after President Obama took office said they believed race relations were generally good.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, in the gauzy afterglow of a stirring election night in Chicago, commentators dared ask whether the United States had finally begun to heal its divisions over race and atone for the original sin of slavery by electing its first black president. It has not. Not even close.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Drug Testing Is Coming to E-Sports
articles.snippet: The Electronic Sports League said on Thursday that it would start testing players for performance-enhancing drugs, a regulation move that would align it with more traditional sports leagues.
articles.abstract: The Electronic Sports League said on Thursday that it would start testing players for performance-enhancing drugs, a regulation move that would align it with more traditional sports leagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lance Armstrong. Alex Rodriguez. Kory Friesen.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Inquiry Sought in Hillary Clinton’s Use of Email
articles.snippet: Since her use of a private email account for State Department business was revealed in March, Hillary Rodham Clinton has repeatedly said she had no classified information on the account.
articles.abstract: Since her use of a private email account for State Department business was revealed in March, Hillary Rodham Clinton has repeatedly said she had no classified information on the account.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update, Aug. 20, 2018: Subsequent developments and later reporting by The Times shed additional light on these events. New details emerged in April 2017 in this Times account of James B. Comey’s handling of the Clinton investigation, as well as in Mr. Comey’s own book, published in April 2018.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: China’s Global Ambitions, Cash and Strings Attached
articles.snippet: The country has invested billions in Ecuador and elsewhere, using its economic clout to win diplomatic allies and secure natural resources around the world.
articles.abstract: The country has invested billions in Ecuador and elsewhere, using its economic clout to win diplomatic allies and secure natural resources around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL CHACO, Ecuador — Where the Andean foothills dip into the Amazon jungle, nearly 1,000 Chinese engineers and workers have been pouring concrete for a dam and a 15-mile underground tunnel. The $2.2 billion project will feed river water to eight giant Chinese turbines designed to produce enough electricity to light more than a third of Ecuador.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Anthem to Buy Cigna Amid Wave of Insurance Mergers
articles.snippet: A combined Anthem-Cigna would serve 53 million insured. The deal comes just weeks after Aetna agreed to acquire Humana for $37 billion.
articles.abstract: A combined Anthem-Cigna would serve 53 million insured. The deal comes just weeks after Aetna agreed to acquire Humana for $37 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two more of the nation’s biggest health insurers are moving to merge, raising the possibility of a potential fight with antitrust regulators.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Lafayette Shooting Adds Another Angry Face in the Gunmen’s Gallery
articles.snippet: John Russell Houser, the suspect in the theater attack that killed two women in Lafayette, La., was also reported to have vented hatred for liberals and the government.
articles.abstract: John Russell Houser, the suspect in the theater attack that killed two women in Lafayette, La., was also reported to have vented hatred for liberals and the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, La. — It was about 20 minutes into the 7 p.m. showing of “Trainwreck” when moviegoers heard a couple of pops, like a sound effect glitch. But when the sounds rang out again it became horribly clear that this was something else entirely.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Richard Pérez-Peña and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: How to Snag a Reservation at That Oh-So-Popular Restaurant
articles.snippet: It takes more than money to get seated at the trendiest dining establishments in places like New York, Los Angeles and Miami.
articles.abstract: It takes more than money to get seated at the trendiest dining establishments in places like New York, Los Angeles and Miami.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a beautiful Saturday evening and you want to go out to a hot new restaurant, maybe splurge on one of those grand Michelin three-star restaurants in New York.

articles.headline: Prison That Held ‘El Chapo’ Is Replica of One He Broke Out of Earlier
articles.snippet: The Mexican prison from which the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, escaped is virtually identical in layout to one he escaped in 2001.
articles.abstract: The Mexican prison from which the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, escaped is virtually identical in layout to one he escaped in 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Ever since the powerful drug lord known as El Chapo escaped from a maximum-security prison through a mile-long tunnel that opened right into the shower of his cell, Mexico has been wondering how his accomplices got their hands on the blueprints to operate with such pinpoint precision.
